lead_paragraph: Companies are not required to record a deferred income tax liability on foreign earnings, which can make earnings seem bigger than they are.

headline.print_headline: Piles of Profit Can Be Seen, Not Touched
headline.main: Piles of Overseas Profits Investors Can See but Not Touch

snippet: Companies are not required to record a deferred income tax liability on foreign earnings, which can make earnings seem bigger than they are.
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column investigates how unreported deferred tax liabilities on foreign corporate profits can be significantly misleading to investors; observes that American companies have avoided paying taxes on some $2.1 trillion in foreign earnings by declaring their intention to re-invest them abroad, though claims are dubious; argues that it has become extremely difficult to calculate just how much of a companies' earnings consists of such foreign profits.
